item.title: Paying someone to portforward
item.dc:creator: @Devastational Devastational
item.description:
@Devastational wrote:

Firewall exceptions?
^
Make sure you’ve done that through your anti-virus (if any) and the control panel firewall.

Also, some times people cannot run their server using their own IP (Like a no-ip.)
Myself on another computer can’t play my server through the NO-IP ip’s. You should ask someone else politely to try testing that if it works from their end. If it works, then great! Just change your own version of the client (not anyone else’s) to 127.0.0.1

If it doesn’t make sense then PM me for more information.

Read full topic

item.title: Paying someone to portforward
item.dc:creator: @ultimatepkvillage ultimatepkvillage
item.description:
@ultimatepkvillage wrote:

^ good information but not all routers work like that. He has a 2wire 2701HB-G which is basically a modem with a built in router & the way to do this one is going through the homepage firewall settings then setting the application he made to the computer. From what I seen everything is setup correctly but it still wont go online.

Read full topic

item.title: Paying someone to portforward
item.dc:creator: @The_Web_Guy The Web Guy
item.description:
@The_Web_Guy wrote:

How to PortForward, the easiest way…

  1. Open up any Web Browser, other than Internet Explorer; Computer may crash.
  2. In the URL bar type in ‘192.168.1.1’, if that doesn’t work go to ‘192.168.0.1’
  3. Login to your router settings, if you haven’t defined a router password, the default username is ‘username’ and password is ‘password’. Sometimes the username can be ‘admin’ and the password can be ‘admin’ as well. Try a couple combinations if it isn’t working the first time.
  4. Navigate to Port-Forwarding options, not Port-Triggering. If you don’t see a clear link that says port-forwarding, look for one that says advanced or networking.
  5. Go to Start > Run
  6. In the small window that pops up, type ‘cmd’
  7. In the black window that comes up after clicking ‘OK’ type in ‘ipconfig’ …
  8. You’ll see something like ‘IPV4 Address . . . . . . . 192.168.1.###’
  9. Take that number (the 192.168.1.###) the ‘#’ should be something different for you, either one, two, or three digits long.
  10. Go back to your router settings, for the service name type in “RSPS” or whatever you’d like, it doesn’t matter.
  11. For where to direct it to put in the 192.168.1.### (Whatever you took note of from ipconfig)
  12. Select TCP.
  13. Enter in starting port and ending port (should be the same). This is whatever the port is that your server is listening to, generally 43594, but sometimes can be 5555.
  14. Save router settings and close the window.

There you go, it isn’t too hard.

Read full topic

[/quote]
To be honest if you can’t port forward then you shoudn’t make a RSPS cause you probably won’t be able to fix glitches and dupes ETC…[/quote]

LMAO port forward is Online Networking, glitches and dupes are java language coding two different things doesn’t matter if he can’t portforward and you shouldn’t judge without knowing them. Also, some providers don’t allow portforwarding through their services.

item.description:
@Broken-Reality wrote:

Dont forget going to computer>Networks>Right click your router>proprieties>Settings>add port and then goto www.CanYouSeeMe.Org and you have to be running the server for it to say “Success”

Read full topic

item.title: Paying someone to portforward
item.dc:creator: @ohokay ohokay
item.description:
@ohokay wrote:

To someone who has never heard about port forwarding it does sound difficult. It is really easy. All you have to do is log into your router, go to advanced setup and there should be a load of boxes for you to write stuff in. Just put your ports and ups in them, click save and you’re done.

I know all routers are different but it’s the same concept for all, there will e an advanced section, or maintenance section within your routers settings.

Read full topic
